instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPBUS_3GH: What is PPBUS_3GH? PPBUS_3GH is a typo of PPBUS_G3H. If you see someone type PPBUS_3GH assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_3GH</SIGNAL> 12.6v , all PP3v42 3.42v, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.4 but no power up from power but or power on pads

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS voltages?
Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and be sure to use original Magsafe 2 60/85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> =3.3v
original MagSafe 2 65w

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
Now post <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
If yes, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> =2.0v

im gonna solder a wire to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  and see if I can simulate pwr button

threads.message: My mistake <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4v

threads.message: I simulated power button it does indeed drop to zero and back up to 3.4V

threads.message: Ok I have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> but it doesn?t fluctuate when I ground the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
Do you mean <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is always high?
In such case, S3 voltages should be present too.
Post voltage at all big coils.
Also check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
Yes it stays high
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> =3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> =5v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> =3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> is water damaged and cap is gone. Hiow important is <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> it?s not grounded just missing end cap. Shouldn?t it power up without it? U 1950 doesn?t look damaged I checked all the resistors around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> they?re values are good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> corroded, usually damage trace to pin 8/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> too.
In such case, rebuild the trace,
Remove <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and inspect all pads (board and chip).

Do you get VCORE?
Post voltage for pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message: I have 3.42v on all areas that should have this voltage present. but not on <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> or trace coming from board. even at the point where it emerges from the board just let of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> I will back track to see where the issue is and diode mode on track is OL. So I?m guessing something got knocked off or open trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message: Ok I removed the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and found the trade gone on pp3v42 on pin 8 I re did the trace and cleaned up the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> 8 pin but I?m thinking this thing might be no good. I?m order a new one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message: Quick question when I connect the fan it brings g3h down. How often does a bad fan bring down a power rail ? Anyway I ordered a new fan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
Fan connects with <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>.
If generates short there, SMC can detect and pulls down <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
Hi ok so I actually repaired the fan connector and fan
touched up the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and it turns on and boots fine. I never installed <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR>. It didn?t seem important. But I figured I?d ask you. How crucial is <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR>? Thanks for your response.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message: Oh and lastly I have a few isl repairs I?d like to get 10k resistor and other things that commonly go around them would you be able to tell me what are the most common so I can purchase them ahead of time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> is not critical; you can forget it.

Buy resistor book kit, like here
[url]https://www.ebay.es/itm/0201-0402-0603-0805-1206-SMD-SMT-Capacitor-Chip-Resistor-Samples-Book-Kit-TZ5/192983430782?hash=item2ceeb5767e:m:mA4fZxxL757MJh-s2VVjdew[/url]
Don't throw money on capacitor kits, or mixed resistors/capacitors.
Buy ONLY resistors, from 0201 to 0805.
1206 is rarely used, but the price is low enough to have it in stock.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light but Dead
threads.message: Awesome thanks
